3.5 stars, rounded upThis was actually far more readable and enjoyable than I would have thought, given its subject. But Bryson is a good stylist and can make even complicated scientific and medical ideas understandable for a lay-reader like me. This is essentially a tour through the body, outlining the history of what we've learned and how we've learned it about each subject. What's especially helpful is the number of readily believed "truths" that Bryson debunks along the way.The most frustrating chapter is the one on Medicine. In short, the USA healthcare system is a disaster of its own making through greed. For example, two objective facts:The USA, per person, spends 2.5 times as much on healthcare than the average of all other wealthy nations. And yet we rank just 31st in life expectancy. One has to wonder what we're getting for the outlandish costs.If nothing else comes out of the Coronavirus debacle in America, we should realize just how dysfunctional and corrupt our healthcare system is and fix it now.

Bill Bryson’s books are like the literary equivalent of the British panel show Qi. Like an episode of the long-running series, his books are filled with tidbits of trivia presented in a quirky and humorous way. While Bryson is often quite ambitious in tackling the subjects that interest him (attempting to explain the universe in 2003’s A Short History of Nearly Everything), no single book should be considered the definitive account on any topic.As indicated above, the disclaimer also applies to The Body. Bryson breaks down the human body and attempts to answer questions about what makes us.. us. The author tackles everything from the top of your head to the tips of your toes and everything in between. Why do we itch? Why are we filled with millions of microbes at any given time? Why are some viruses deadly and others pass through without even a sign they were there? Why on a long enough timeline, do we all eventually get cancer? These are just a few of the questions Bryson tackles in his new book.There were many moments where I audibly gasped reading this book and struggled with whether I should tell my hypochondriac partner what I read. I did read her one bit about a woman who scratched through her skull and into her brain during sleep and judging by Alaina’s scream, I hesitated to read any more unsettling parts aloud.It’s amazing the level of sophistication we have only now when it comes to surgery. Obviously, things evolve, but it is horrific to hear about the irresponsible way we even practiced lobotomies and brain surgery in the mid 1900s. No sterilization, just cram an icepick into your eye sockets and wiggle it around until you sever key components of the human brain. There’s no way we could have gotten to where we are now without having to experiment over the years, but I could think of better things to do than trying to transfuse our blood stream with beer and milk.One of the most interesting parts of the book deals with how the brain interprets the information sent by our eyes. Bryson writes that it takes one fifth of a second for what we see to be interpreted by the brain. So we are never truly seeing the present. Wild, eh? So, our brain makes up the difference by forecasting what the world will look like a fifth of a second from now. So, as Bryson says, “we are all living in a world that does not exist yet.”One thing I will say – I’m no expert in science let alone how the human body works. Maybe I have somewhat of an idea of how mine struggles to get through the day, but I couldn’t tell you if Bryson made any big errors or mistakes in this book. Luckily, there are reviews like this one who can speak more authoritatively on the matter. While the reviewer did point out a few errors, the majority of the book seems to be sound.I really enjoyed this read and definitely recommend it.. I feel like I learned a lot, or at least things that I can bring up randomly in conversations. For example, to build Benedict Cumberbatch from scratch would cost you $151,578.46. So, there’s that.

You know what you are going to get from a Bryson book of this type. Quirky stories aligned to historical/modern facts about the subject at hand. The subject at hand is you. Well, your body. All of it. From top to toe and all bits in-between. From the time you were conceived to the time you die.What a great journey it is. I was boring the family by stopping them watching Saturday evening TV by telling them facts about their body that they didn’t really want to hear that I found fascinating. Do you know that 59 elements are needed to construct a human being. Carbon, oxygen, hydrogen, nitrogen, calcium and phosphorus account for 99.1%. Did you know that the formal name for skin is the cutaneous system. The inner layer is called the dermis. The outer layer is called the epidermis. Skin and hair are made largely of the same stuff – keratin. There are so many more examples of this. You can see why they wanted to lock me away in the kitchen to read and stop bothering them.The thing is with Bryson is that he knows how to weave a really complicated subject into a text that is readable, entertaining and educating. Admittedly a lot of the facts and stats he throws at you are mind-boggling. I took about 5 pages of A4 notes. It could have been a lot more but I would have ended up just copying the book.The research is, of course, extensive. He spoke to so many people and must have read a load of medical journals and books. Some of the stories on these early, mainly Victorian, medical pioneers who would experiment on themselves to see if certain techniques, drugs and even surgery would work sometimes with great effect but a lot of the time failing resulting in terrible injuries including death.What do you think the most devastating disease in history is? It infected nearly everyone that was exposed to it. It killed 30% of its victims. 500 million died.In 1872 Charles Darwin published a book on expressions and it showed that all people, whatever their race, shared a common heritage. Fear, anger, surprise, pleasure, disgust and sorrow are universal. The most universal of them all is the smile. Keep Smiling everyone.

I have been a Bill Bryson fan for quite some time. I first read A Short History of Nearly Everything when it came out, and I was stunned at how much I understood and liked science. I even understood string theory for a total of about six minutes. But it was something!I have been on the Bryson tip since then, usually with rewarding results. I have loved his books on travel, the English language, Shakespeare, and more. I couldn’t quite get into At Home, but I think I might want to retry that one, because I loved this book. It does everything that a listicle will do for your sense of understanding, but probes deeper and casts a wider net. It is so much more interesting than those pithy articles from the Internet.We get to almost all of it: birth and death, sight and taste, emotion and sex. Some of the historical names get lost in the morass, but that doesn’t matter so much if, when you’re reading it, it compels you this deeply. And indeed it compels, giving us history of communicable diseases, the dividing line between when a zygote becomes a baby, and how, exactly, my color blind eyes work.There should be a tendency to get grim. There are so many statistics, so many I don’t knows, that it might be simpler for Bryson to simply shrug and say science doesn’t know much. But one of Bryson’s strengths is that he loves to follow footnotes to sources. The Body is thorough; but that doesn’t mean it’s dry. I listened to the audiobook read by Bryson himself. I love his orating voice, and the way he emphasizes certain words in his half-British/half-American accent. He is very good at what he does here, in both delivery and content. If you really like Brysons earlier work, I highly recommend trying this one out. You won’t regret it.

My first book by Bill Bryson was "A Short History of Nearly Everything." Since reading it, I have frequently included a Bryson book or two in my yearly reading and have suggested them to others. The Body is sure to be another book I will regularly recommend (and in fact already have).The book itself winds through the system's of the body one after another. Bryson discusses what makes up the system, the important discoveries and discovers of parts in the system, always with an eye toward what makes for a good story. Finishing with the systems, he moves on to the functions of the body, illness and causes of disease, and finally death. Even knowing a good amount about anatomy and scientific history, I found myself learning while reading things book. This was particularly true when he discussed new research and interviews with scientists on the cutting edge of physiology or disease research. However, don't mistake this as a boring textbook. While this does not contain the wit and sarcasm of his travelogues or even Brief History, Bryson has a style of writing that keeps you engaged and reading well past the time when you should have gone to bed. I recommend this book for anyone interested in anatomy in particular or science as a whole. You are sure to learn something and have fun doing it. Thank you to the publisher and Netgalley for the opportunity to read a pre-release copy this book.

For me this one was just ok. It’s likely to be more interesting to someone who has little medical knowledge, as much of the material he covered I already knew. I did enjoy some of the historical context he provided. I was disconcerted by some of his errors, though, and it made me wonder what mistakes he might have made that I didn’t know enough to catch. For example, he stated that all senses except smell are routed through the hypothalamus. They actually go through the thalamus. That might seem like a minor error, but it’s pretty basic neuroscience, and even my Intro Psych students know it. It was also a little annoying to listen to him read the book even though I generally enjoy him as a narrator. He mispronounced a number of medical/scientific terms (systole, diastole, encephalitis, Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease, etc), which again seems nitpicky, but it took away from the experience for me. I did learn a few interesting things, though. For example, apparently left-handed kids who are forced to write with their right hands are at increased risk of stuttering, which I found fascinating.I don’t want to dog on this book too much. I think Bill Bryson is fantastic, generally. But I would recommend A Walk in the Woods, A Short History of Nearly Everything, and The Life and Times of the Thunderbolt Kid far, far above this one.

I'm becoming increasingly convinced Bill Bryson is one of the great prose stylists of the English language. That sounds bizarre, I know, but look at this: "The skin consists of an inner layer called the dermis and an outer epidermis. The outermost surface of the epidermis, called the stratum corneum, is made up entirely of dead cells. It is an arresting thought that all that makes you lovely is deceased. Where body meets air, we are all cadavars. These outer skin cells are replaced every month. We shed skin copiously, almost carelessly; some twenty five thousand flakes a minute, over a million pieces every hour. Run a finger along a dusty shelf, and you are in large part clearing a path through fragments of your former self. Silently and remorselessly we turn to dust."This goes on for 500 pages without a single boring paragraph. Essentially, he uses every tool a writer has to supercharge information--and he's incredibly good at it. The book is often quite funny, but occasionally quite profound or even shocking. I've devoured each of his science-themed books in a few days, and it seems I won't be able to resist at least trying out the ones on language.

My first Bryson book was A Walk in the Woods. It was hilarious, all the while sneaking in some education. I went to read almost everything he has in print. So when I saw this title on my ARC list, I was pretty excited, even though human anatomy might be my least favorite subject.I could hold my own now if I needed to critique a television medical drama from the knowledge I gained in reading this ginormous 400-page tome of humanness. It's a partial history of science and part straight-up anatomy.It's the owner's manual that no one has thought to hand out. Only this isn't some hard to understand volume; it's in plain English. I didn't take Anatomy at school and the only text I've encountered while homeschooling was nowhere near as readable as this is. If you are a science geek, you'll devour this. If you are a Bryson fan, he'll drag you into being interested, and if you wanted to use this as a high school science text, I'd support you. I'm probably going to make it required reading at our house.

I REALLY liked this book. I am biased because in my imagination Bill Bryson is a friend with whom I chat often and from whom I learn all sorts of fascinating things. In reality, Mr Bryson is an author whom I’ve never met but who entertained me for the last two and a half months with facts about the human body that I have repeated aloud so often to friends and family that every time they find my words interesting they ask me if I learned it from “your Body Book”. Most of the time the answer was yes. I learned so many things in each and every chapter. Perhaps the most important to me was that a person cannot “undo sitting” or negate its detrimental effects on the body by activity or exercise. As a result of this singular fact, I read many of these 400 pages while standing. True fact. This is one of those books that at the end I am better off, mind and body, as it happens, for having read!

Bill Bryson teaches you everything you didn’t know you wanted to know about the human body in this book. Bryson takes on the brain and skin and hair and the skeleton and the immune system and lungs and food and guts and sleep and birth and nerves and pain and disease and cancer and death. He tells the stories of the scientists behind the discoveries about the body. Everything is backed with science and footnotes, and that’s part of the delight in this book, but the other part are the anecdotes about the body and the people studying the body, and that’s a true joy.This is the kind of book that (probably) drives everyone else in your family crazy; you read a little and you can’t help yourself from reading parts of it aloud, and then you laugh together and walk away, and you read some more, and then you share some more, and on and on to the end. A new favorite nonfiction read.

I think whether or not you enjoy this book depends on your current level of knowledge about the subject matter. For me there was nothing new in the is book and to some extent an over emphasis on figures such as the length of this, that and the other. There were also blatantly wrong statements. Bryson describes a cancer hospital in the Netherlands, its patients (all ventilated according to the author) scooting around on toy cars or bicycles. I feel he must be referring to naso-gastric tubes rather than ones to help you breathe. Such a mistake is unforgivable not only on the part of the author but of the editors. Readers should be able to trust the information they are given in non-fiction

Enter the wonderful world of Bill Bryson who has a master's touch for explaining things in a way that we all understand and are fascinated by. When he takes apart our body, system by system, piece by piece we not only understand more about our inner workings but we have been thoroughly entertained along the way. He is the master of anecdote, the king of clever tidbits of knowledge and easygoing writing style gives you a greater appreciation for the intricate machine we call our body. Here's to not-stuffy science! My thanks to the publisher for the advance copy.

What Bill Bryson did for the home, in his book "At Home: A Short History of Private Life", he now does for the human body in "The Body: A Guide for Occupants." This books is full of wonderful and sometimes quirky facts about the human body. Great as a fun read, and it's quite comprehensive in depth of the human body. As Bill Gates said, "The human body is the most complex system ever created. The more we learn about it, the more appreciation we have about what a rich system it is."*I read an advance copy and was not compensated.

One of my favorite books of the year! Bryson made me appreciate how amazing and wonderful our bodies truly are. It is a miracle that each one of us have the opportunity to live. I appreciated how it went area-by-area through the body including some analyses of the lesser appreciated functions like equilibrium, sleep, and more.I think the title "a guide for occupants" lives up to its name. If you have an interest in your body and/or human medicine, this is an incredibly entertaining and accessible guide.

Very interesting, and also terrifying in several spots (you don't want to know the surgery procedure for bladder stones and for mastectomies in the 17th-18th centuries, sweet merciful Asclepeius you do NOT want to know). Also moderately terrifying is how often Bryson and the many doctors and scientists he consulted for this book admit that this organ/procedure/portion of the brain does X...but we don't know how, or why. Honestly, the book could be alternately titled "The Body: How the F*** Does It Work?"

This was fairly good; pretty standard Bryson. There were plenty of chuckles, and lots of OH MY GOD SERIOUSLY? I don't think the bar is high for that, because the body is wow no matter what. But one of Bryson's serious talents is to distill big things down to understandable chunks, and he definitely succeeds in that here.But also, there is a LOT LOT LOT of fatphobia in this book. Like so much I *almost* put it down. So I don't know, if you're triggered by that, definitely avoid this.
Funny, smart, entertaining, and thoughtful. A great read for people who like Mary Roach.

I'm well-versed in anatomy and physiology, having been a nurse for more decades than I care to admit. I wasn't sure there would be much new information in this book. Boy, was I wrong!Interesting details about every body system; information that has been gleaned from research and factual sources.I enjoyed the audio version of The Body: A Guide for Occupants, with the author being the narrator. I'm guessing the book is just as interesting.

This book was a blast to read. Unoputdownable (I love that word). If you stopped to mark every interesting factoid, the entire book would be underlined. This must have been the easiest book in the world to write, especially for such a well-known and well-connected writer.   ***Going for regular walks reduces the risk of heart attack or stroke by 31 percent. An analysis of 655,000 people in 2012 found that being active for just eleven minutes a day after the age of forty yielded 1.8 years of added life expectancy. Being active for an hour or more a day improved life expectancy by 4.2 years. ***The fact is, you can quickly undo a lot of exercise by eating a lot of food, and most of us do. ***A study of eighteen thousand runners in Denmark concluded that people who jog regularly can expect to live five to six years longer on average than non-joggers. But is that because jogging truly is that beneficial, or is it because people who jog tend to lead healthy, moderate lives anyway and are bound to have improved outcomes over us more slothful types, with or without sweatpants? ***In one well-known experiment cited by the British academic Steve Jones, a test subject ran a marathon on a treadmill while the room temperature was gradually raised from minus 49 degrees Fahrenheit to 131 degrees Fahrenheit—roughly the limits of human tolerance at both extremes. Despite the subject’s exertions and the great range of temperatures, his core body temperature deviated by less than one degree over the course of the exercise. ***As an experiment, we asked a lady who was completely blind—she had lost her rods and cones as a result of a genetic disease—to tell us when she thought the lights in the room were switched on or off. She told us not to be ridiculous because she couldn’t see anything, but we asked her to try anyway. It turned out she was right every time. Even though she had no vision—no way of ‘seeing’ the light—her brain detected it with perfect fidelity at a subliminal level. She was astonished. We all were.” ***As the American academic Marlene Zuk has put it, “Old age is not a recent invention, but its commonness is.”
Typical Bill Bryson: well-written, humorous, and extremely informative!

I have read - and enjoyed - several of Bryson's earlier books, so his name always catches my eye. This one, his latest, is not at all a memoir, but instead a rather comprehensive view of human biology. This overview touches on many subjects - from the specifics of diseases, impacts of lifestyle choices, details on how organs function alongside quick biographical highlights of many Novel prize winners and others who have made significant discoveries in medicine and deepening your understanding of your own body.There is a lot crammed into this volume - with many interesting footnotes, anecdotes and facts that are fun to share as you read along. The chapters are clearly broken down by subject and though there are a few references to information revealed in later or earlier chapters, for the most part, there isn't even a reason to read this consecutively (so if you are the most interested in the heart - start there!). I think this would be a perfect book to slowly read - a friend of mine mentions that she has a few books always on the go like that (one on her nightstand for just before bed reading, another in the car for reading while waiting on her kids in the pick up line). Because I did read it consecutively, without breaks, it did stand out that Bryson really stressed the poor health of America over his adopted country of Great Britain. I don't think this would have been as obvious had I read this more slowly, over a longer period of time. It is an interesting read and one that definitely feels well-researched. I can see this as a nice addition to your home reference library. And I am curious to see what direction Bryson will go in next.

I never would have guessed that a book about the human body could be so interesting. I loved this book as it had so much great information. If you just want to read a thousand interesting facts, this is the book for you.-1.6% of of all good exported in the U.S. are sales of plasma-The sense of smell is the only one of the five basic senses not mediated by the hypothalamus. Information instead goes straight to the olfactory cortex. Smell also accounts for 70% of flavor. - In one well known experiment, a test subject ran a marathon on a treadmill while the room temperature gradually raised from -49 degrees Fahrenheit to 131 degrees. The runners core body temperature deviated by less than one degree over the course of the exercise.- From 1973 to 2011, the average sperm count in Western nations fell by more than 50 percentThe book also has a lot of history about how discoveries regarding the human body were made. Many of them were accidental. Others were more malicious. I had previously read about the horrific experiments conducted by Nazi scientists during WWII on prisoners and Jews but until this book, I was unaware that the Japanese did the same thing against the Chinese during the war at a location called Unit 731 in which it's estimated that 250 thousand people died. One of the most interesting non-fiction books I've ever read. I'd recommend it to anyone

Bill Bryson, through extensive reading, has compiled a book all about the body. He outlines the history of acquiring knowledge from the most conceivable moment up to the present day, citing the discoveries of various parts of the body when they occurred and by whom. Myths are dispelled such as taking vitamin C will help get rid of a cold or that we need to drink eight glasses of water a day. He discusses practices to help an individual live a healthy, quality of life such as couch potatoes (those sitting six or more hours a day) can benefit by walking around during commercials to burn 180 calories an hour or just standing to burn 107 calories an hour. Recommendations by the World Health Organization such as the daily recommendation for sugar intake is a maximum of five teaspoons are also presented. A muliitude of diseases have come and gone, only to replaced by another disease such as the Heartland virus in 2018. Now there is the Coronavirus which is new since the publication of The Body. How operations have evolved over the years with some horrendous descriptions of earlier operations such as the mastectomy of Fanny Burney, an English novelist, in 1810. Bryson reiterates Daniel E. Lieberman, professor of human evolutionary biology at Harvard: belief that 70 percent of the diseases that kill us could easily be preventable if we would just live sensibly.

I imagine Bill Bryson standing in front of a mirror doing his thing, with a sudden moment of clarity one day--I know nothing at all about this body of mine. Let me find out more. This book is what I imagine would be the outcome of that moment. This is a sweeping and wide-ranging account of your body from head to toe (with cameos by the various non-human organisms that make us who we are). Bryson chooses to focus on facts and stories--what we know, and how we came to know this, which makes for some very engaging stories. Some themes recur throughout--how a lot of what we assume is common knowledge is myth (8 glasses of water a day, using only 10% of our brain, our body having 10 times more microbes as human cells), how we cannot trust corporates to do the right thing (the opioid crisis, the food industry shoving bad things down our throats, the lobbying by the tobacco industry), and just how little we truly understand when we dig deeper (how does an itch arise?) It's a tome for sure, but the length feels just right. If there was anything I had a problem with, it was the author's focus on the White world--there is a touch of Euro/America centrism that feels outdated in this age.

I have been wanting to read Bill Bryson for a while now and was thrilled when I got this ebook from my library. Timing is everything and I was the first person to check it out at my library! The book is filled with amazing facts and stories about how the human body works, medical science, and the history of medicine. The author's particular writing style, relaying all these science facts within anecdotal stories, is what makes it so entertaining and fun to read. And it definitely helps with my retention of scientific information, especially as I get older! Several parts of the book were devoted to the brain, memory and aging, so, yes, I am sure I was his target audience! My main take-away from this book is despite all our advances and increased knowledge of the human body, we really know so little and so much of what we know is still theory and guesswork. I highly recommend The Body. It reminds me of Mary Roach's writing style. I will be looking out for more books by Bill Bryson.

Intetesting and, in parts, fascinating. The most fascinating thing is that Bryson marvels at the incredible human body yet sadly attributes everything solely to evolution and won't even consider the possibility of it all pointing to a creator God.

Bill Bryson is a gifted writer, deftly melding facts with wit to expose humorous aspects of the human condition and the world around us. As a result, he can unpack any topic into the most fascinating thing you’ve ever read. The Body: A Guide for Occupants is no exception. Each chapter focuses on a body part or process, similar to the format of his book At Home focusing on the house and its functions. As with his other books, he has a knack for tracking down mind-boggling statistics and facts. So while some of these you may recall from biology class, he manages to find other intricate details and relays them in a clear, witty manner. And while we have come such a long way in learning and discovering the body's inner workings, there's much that's still a mystery to medical science. I just kept thinking, "Wow - this is the place that houses all of my thoughts, feelings and physical attributes and there's still so much I don't know about it." We truly are a work in progress.

Fascinating, extensively researched guide to the human body and what makes it work. Filled with both facts and interesting historical and contemporary stories, this was a great read. It’s amazing to me how much we have no knowledge of - or guesses at best.As others have noted, not for the squeamish or those bothered by descriptions of sickness/disease/etc. I’m generally not a squeamish person, but one woman’s first-hand account of her 1810 mastectomy was extremely difficult to read.Unfortunately, the gender binary is very much enforced, especially in the chapter on reproductive organs. I wonder if this is a reflection of the comparatively small amount of scientific research on gender as a spectrum. I think it would have been good to at least mention the concept of being trans though.

I love Bill Bryson's writing - he's nothing if not thorough in his research and he always puts on a whimsical spin on things, regardless of the situation or subject. He has a wonderful outlook on things that I wish most people would adapt into their daily lives. Somehow, finding the humor in things that seem to not have a jot of it brings out the best in yourself and can calm you down.Anyways, that being said, there are facts galore in this look at what makes you you that may or may not distress you. Always entertaining and interesting despite being oft times gross and - well - grosser, Bill Bryson does not disappoint.The ending (which is about your ending) I found to be rather short. But life sometimes goes that way doesn't it.

I love Bill Bryson’s writing style and he did not disappoint in this book. It’s heavy on science, but in a good way with fun facts thrown in- like the surface area of our lungs (if they were spread out) would cover a tennis court. And we excrete millions of red blood cells a day. Wow!It’s a long book and sometimes I skimmed a bit of the history having to do with the researchers/discoverers of certain theories/drugs/genes/diseases/etc. but it was a very smooth blend of “here’s how this discovery in 1865 got us to where we are today”. Each chapter is a different part of the body and I feel much more educated on how our bodies work and the true miracle that we are!

*I was given an advanced copy of this title via NetGalley in exchange for an honest review*What can I say about Bill Bryson that hasn't already been said? He's a wonderful author with an amazingly articulate and witty voice. This particular book is jam-packed with facts, to the point where I had to read it one chapter at a time or my brain would get overwhelmed. It's a dense book and might be a slow read, but Bryson's voice gives it life in a way that other authors would lose my interest. He keeps it witty and engaging the entire time.

Ever since reading “Little Dribbling,” I have been watching for a new book from Bill Bryson. He’s known best for his science-related books, of course, so he is sure to please all of his fans with this latest offering. And what an offering it is! An homage to the great gift that is the human body, this narrative is filled with all of the facts – both fun and serious – you need to truly respect what The Body does for us. Between Bill Bryson and Malcom Gladwell, I am a happy literary-science camper. Got more? Bring it on!I met this book at Auntie's Bookstore in Spokane, WA

I find the human body to be so fascinating. As a medical professional, I had to undergo many years of learning about anatomy, physiology, and biochemistry to earn my degree. I loved learning about the science that makes us human, and I still do! Thus, The Body: A Guide for Occupants, was a real winner with me. Bryson has a way of relating information that makes reading nonfiction feel fun and engaging. I recommend this read for anyone who enjoys learning about science and humans and what makes us, us.

Needs more funny.The human body is amazing in two different ways: one, for what we know about it and how we came to know it; and two, what we don't know about it and the efforts we have made to get answers. This book needed to choose one or the other, or it needed to tell it all. As it is, it seems stuck in the middle. I wanted more stories and anecdotes. Bryson seems to have forgotten himself in the writing of this trying to get through the various workings of different body parts.

(Bryson, indeed, quotes Roach quite a bit.)The fault here may lie partially with me: I have perhaps read too many pop science books.

As an insecure know-nothing myself, I always appreciate it when a nonfiction book frequently repeats that the best that can be said about its topic is, “we just don’t know.”But seriously, Bryson’s pop-sci writing is always exemplary: succinct, informative, original, and touched with just enough humor and anecdote.
I liked it but, you know, there were some things I thought were missed and glossed over... but I'm an anatomist, so I don't expect a lay-reader to be bothered by any of that.
Bryson was his entertaining self and showed the right amount of awe for the wonders of the human body, but mostly it felt like he was going through the motions.
While this was highly interesting, I feel like it wasn't quite as charming as some of Bryson's other work. I would still thoroughly recommend this though!
This was easy to understand for someone who isn’t scientifically inclined. I need the hardcover ASAP!!! Most definitely re-reading this!
I finished this book and am now a licensed physician I think.

This book should replace the current biology textbooks at schools. It's much more accurate, up-to-date AND extremely interesting. I feel that I have learnt more about human body than I ever did during all my school years (a long time ago). The author gives us a tour of the human body through all its systems such as integumentary system, nervous system and respiratory system. We explore the role of every single element of the body, we learn about how we came to have the current medical knowledge and what we are still missing, as well as about everything that can go wrong in the marvelous yet imperfect machine that the human body is.The author focuses a lot on people to whom we owe everything we know today. Many of the geniuses that propelled the medical knowledge forward were often very flawed or outright horrible people outside of their profession. It gives perspective on the people that refuse to read extraordinary books written by morally doubtful writers. It's about separating people from their work.What I found the most terrifying just how much we still don't know about our own bodies. We can do close to nothing about autoimmune diseases (which I was unfortunately already aware of, since I myself suffer from one), cancer and other things in pretty every single human system.There were also many facinating trivia facts, for example: - Autoimmune diseases are "sexist" and 80% of sufferers are women. - Many women needlessly die of heart attacks, because they are misdiagnosed due to the male bias in what we know about the symptoms (women often have completely different symptoms than men!). - The race, which has played and unfortunately still plays such a huge role in human history and modern time, is nothing but a thin layer of cells in the outer skin. - The idea of growing human organs in animals for transplanting gave a creepy Oryx and Crake vibe *shudders*. - Humans enjoy animal suffering. They torture animal in labs and they call it animal testing. The problem is that animals are different species than humans and they have very different metabolism, suffer from different diseases, etc. So people inflict horrible suffering on them, and there are no real benefits for humanity, apart from sadists enjoying themselves. And guess where a lot of worst diseases come from, including the biggest epidemics? Animal farming. Karma is a bitch. *munches on a vegan burger* Except we all suffer for the pleasure of meat-eaters' taste buds. - Cancerous cells appear in our bodies a few times a week and are promptly detected and destroyed by our immune system. Until they aren't. If we live long enough, we pretty much all get cancer. Scary…
Personal note
So this is a note for my future self, to give the interesting context in which I was reading this book. As I write this review, we are right in the middle of Covid-19 pandemic. I didn't plan on reading a medical non-fiction featuring diseases and epidemics now. I was waiting in the library queue for this book for a few months, long before anyone suspected what times we would find ourselves in. My hold finally arrived when the first news about unknown virus in China started spreading around the world. I got opportunity to read this book slowly instead of hurrying through (since renewal for popular books is not possible), because the national lock-down happened, the libraries closed from day to day and I was left with all my check-outs for unknown amount of time. As such, when I reached the chapter about infectious diseases, I was in my third (or fourth?) week of working from home, just as most of the people who were fortunate not to lose their jobs. And then this quotation came up: The fact is, we are really no better prepared for a bad outbreak today than we were when Spanish flu killed tens of millions of people a hundred years ago. The reason we haven't had another experience like that isn't because we have been especially vigilant. It's because we have been lucky.Well, it seems that our luck has finally run out…

I had pretty mixed feelings about this book. I’m a big fan of Bryson as a humorist. I value a good laugh over many other things in life, and Bryson is one of the funniest people I’ve ever encountered. The Life and Times of the Thunderbolt kid is possibly the funniest book I’ve ever read in my entire life. I came across my first Bill Bryson book on the dusty shelf of a house in which I was staying in Europe a few years ago, it was The Lost Continent, Travels in Small-Town America. That book had me in splits for the rest of my trip and brought me so much joy. I still quote it on road trips in America. In short, I think Bryson excels as an essayist, a travel writer, and a humorist in general. But he has this other big passion, to catalogue. I enjoyed a Short History of Nearly Everything, but I went into this book with a rather more critical scientific eye because as a neuroscientist, my education is in the life sciences. The tone and writing of the book were excellent and entertaining, we already know Bryson is a dynamite writer. This book was totally enjoyable. But factually, I’m not as convinced. The book is impressive in its scope and detail, especially for a non-scientist, and Bryson’s joy in learning the material comes through robustly. However the actual biological information contained in this book is kind of a hodgepodge. Some sections are really well nuanced and do a great job of citing good primary resources. For example, the section on leptin was presented better than many endocrinology texts I’ve read, making it clear that leptin is a hormone that is thought to signal a paucity of body fat when it is low, and stimulates appetite to remedy the situation. Leptin does not work as a supplement for overweight people, because above a certain threshold, it does not affect appetite appreciably. It did not evolve to signal as a regulator of excessive weight gain. The section on the prostate was also really well presented. Bryson discusses at some length the false positive rate of many preventative cancer screenings, PSA among them. This section mostly draws on the work of Richard J Ablin, who invented the PSA test, making him a very appropriate primary resource. But then, throughout the book Bryson does things like cite Daniel Lieberman extensively about things like the biochemistry of nutrition, even though Lieberman’s education is in anthropology. He’s not an expert on any of the fields Bryson cites him for, he just speaks about them accessibly, and as a result, much of the factual content of these sections is questionable. As a neuroscientist, I took special issue with the portion on neurogenesis over the lifespan. Bryson claims that it is hotly debated whether humans make new brain cells as we age. This is not true, there is a strong consensus in neuroscience that new neurons are formed throughout the lifespan. Bryson points to two opposing studies, one finding that new neurons were made in the hippocampus, and others finding that they were not. This is a misinterpretation of the second study, which actually found that the new neurons in the hippocampus were formed elsewhere and migrated into the hippocampus. Additionally, he claims that whether or not we make new neurons is sort of a moot point because it is nowhere near enough to compensate for the rampant neuronal loss we experience with aging. This is completely untrue and based on studies largely conducted in the 1950’s-1970’s which did not correct for volumetric changes in the aging brain. The best evidence to date says that there is no significant neuronal loss associated with normal aging, or that we lose perhaps 2-4% of neurons over the lifespan in normal aging. While there is some shrinkage of neuronal outgrowths, cell loss is not typical outside of pathological conditions like Alzheimer’s disease. In short, this book is interesting, funny, and a charming read. But if something in it seems radical or hard to believe to you, I’d encourage investigating other primary sources of info about that topic.

In his Bill Bryson breezy prose, the author has chosen the human body as the subject for this tome and because that’s just the way he writes, it’s eminently readable - and enjoyable. I found myself saying Huh or outright laughing on many occasions. For instance, “Ollivere gently incised and peeled back a sliver of skin about a millimeter thick from the arm of a cadaver. That’s all that race is —a sliver of epidermis.’” That got a Huh from me when I first read it and another Huh as I reread it just now.When he divulges information, he adds a example that we can relate to illustrate his point. For instance when he tells us that the region of the forebrain is associated with pleasure which grows to its largest size in teen years. “That is why the sensations you feel as a teenager are more intense than at any other time of life. And I had to read that part out loud to my husband. In fact, I had to read out loud to him on several occasions. I’m sure he’s glad I’ve finished the book.There are factoids scattered though the chapters, like how MSG got it’s bad reputation. We read about the rise in diabetes throughout the world which probably comes as a surprise to no one. But who knew that that type I diabetes in Finland has risen 550 percent since 1950 and continues to rise almost every where else at a rate of 3-5 percent. No one knows why. Really?!!I thoroughly enjoyed this book, as I do all of Bryson’s books, and if you’re wondering how a book on the human body could be engaging, take my word for it. It is.

Writing a popular science book that's understandable and fun for the lay(wo)man is one thing, but to make it fun and worth listening to for someone who does know the minutia of the topic is another. I've spent a lot of time and money learning and forgetting about the intricacies of the human body: sitting through hours of lectures; poring over pages of facts, figures, diagrams; and seeing it off the page as well. For me, this book could have ended up being a more watered down slightly less pedantic review book - and that would have probably bored me to death. However, The Body: A Guide for Occupants isn't written by someone trying to teach "plebes" about their field, it isn't written by a science writer at all. Bill MoFo Bryson is the author of this book, and if anyone could find a way to make something interesting to everyone regardless of background, it's him. I may be biased, several of Bill Bryson's books rank among my favorite books of all time (A Walk in the Woods: Rediscovering America on the Appalachian Trail, and I'm a Stranger Here Myself: Notes on Returning to America After Twenty Years Away in particular) so perhaps I'm just predisposed to liking the work he puts out. While there is a very basic rundown of the different parts of the body, their functions, and other related topics (conversations on public health, microbiology, epidemiology, etc...) there's also a lot of trivia, history, anecdotes that help everyone understand that we really know very little about the human body - but we worked hard to get there.The book is written in Bryson's characteristic fun and light manner, but it's full of information presented in a way that makes it feel that he's just as overjoyed to learn about each tidbit as you should be reading it. It's joyful education, even more so when listening to the audiobook which he reads. Listening to an emotive person joyfully explaining the different parts and functions of the brain is a completely different experience from listening to a droning soporific professor. I can't really speak for how info-dumpy it may be, a lot of it is just refreshing my memory of things I know followed by interesting bits of trivia or history that I either didn't remember or didn't learn. Honestly, the non-science parts were more interesting to me because it's fascinating to see what parts of history gets left behind. There's a lot of backstabbing in the research and academic world, that's for sure.I do wonder if he wishes that the book was released next year, because while his chapter on the pandemic that would bring our society to it's knees was pretty spot on, it would have definitely been different knowing what we know now. Though all the experts he interviewed were pretty accurate on the characteristics of a virus that could cause a pandemic, and how unprepared the world would be for it. People keep asking the question "who could have known?!", well, apparently a lot of people - enough that Bill Bryson has a whole chapter on it before the pandemic started.This is a fun book, and well narrated by Bryson. This is the perfect light but informative non-fiction book to listen to while walking the dog.

Like many readers, I very much enjoy Bill Bryson's non-fiction work.  I picked up his newest publication, The Body: A Guide for Occupants having not read any of his writing for such a long time, and was so pleased that I did.  I was reminded once more of how warm his prose is, and how fascinating his subjects.Many of Bryson's books are essentially travel writing, in which he writes about countries and regions which he has lived or travelled within - the United States, United Kingdom, and Africa are just three examples.  The Body is something a little different to these personal geographies, though.  It is far more science-based than much of his work, and does not include many personal stories, something which his books tend to be built upon.  It looks inward, trying to decipher what really makes a human being.The Body has been split into many chapters, each of which focuses upon a distinctive part of the human body.  These range from 'The Immune System' and 'The Brain' to 'Into the Nether Regions'.  These chapters are incredibly thorough; there is not an element of the body which has not been explored in some way.  He moves seamlessly from one topic to another.  With his chapter on the skin, for instance, he moves from bacteria found on the skin to the phenomenon of itching, and then the reasons as to why we lose hair as we age, all in less than two pages.Bryson writes about so many things here, including the beginning of forensic science; microbes and proteins, and their functions and uses within the body; viruses; advances in medicine; evolutionary changes within human anatomy; how different parts of us age, and the consequences felt; the myriad benefits of exercise; and the wonder found within the structure of our bones.  He writes about so many things that are known about the human body, and also the surprising number of elements which remain a mystery.  Bryson introduces several medical conundrums, interesting cases which cannot be solved.Bryson has chosen to begin The Body with rather a fascinating chapter, entitled 'How to Build a Human', which calculates how expensive it would be to procure all of the elements which make up the human body - clue: a lot.  This memorable prologue, as it were, sets the tone for the book, and feels perfectly placed.As ever, Bryson's writing in The Body is both absorbing and accessible.  He grapples with complex ideas throughout the book, but presents everything in a way which can be read and understood by newcomers to this subject.  He introduces myriad facts in marvellous ways, which really make one think; for instance, 'In the second or so since you started this sentence, your body has made a million red blood cells.'  One can see from the outset that Bryson clearly has quite a passion for this subject, and this shines throughout, as does his humour.  Throughout, Bryson consults experts in different fields, and also mentions a lot of books which focus upon biology along the way.The Body is a book which one can learn, unsurprisingly, a great deal from.  I have always been fascinated by biology and the human body, and have read a few books on the subject before, but I found myself learning new facts throughout.  Although there is such a great deal packed into the pages of The Body, and a great deal of impeccable research has clearly been done, it never feels saturated with information, and can easily be read from cover to cover.  The Body is, all in all, a fact-lover's dream, which demonstrates how wonderful the human body is, in all of its strangeness.I will end this review with a passage which I, personally, found fascinating: 'The most remarkable part of all is your DNA.  You have a metre of it packed into every cell, and so many cells that if you formed all the DNA in your body into a single fine strand it would stretch ten billion miles, to beyond Pluto.  Think of it: there is enough of you to leave the solar system.  You are in the most literal sense cosmic.'

Some of the details he shared hit a little too close to home.Here is a sample of some things that I found really interesting: - The outer layer of your skin is almost entirely dead cells. So when you look at a person, what you are seeing is mostly cadaver. - When you sunburn, your skin turns red because your blood vessels are swelling up. That is also why you feel hot to the touch. - Your body produces 5-10 ounces of tears every day. That's almost a full can of soda. - If everyone in the world were as overweight as Americans, it would be the equivalent of adding 1 billion people to the planet. - Food stays in your body for about 55 hours if you are a grown man. It's about 72 hours if you are a grown woman. - Poop is primarily brown because of expired red blood cells. - Gravity affects us differently based on our mass. So, a child half your height only experiences 1/132nd of the force of gravity when falling. This is why kids seem so indestructible. Just like he did in "A Short History of Nearly Everything", Bryson doesn't hesitate to say how much we still don't know about the human body. For example, modern opinion is that man is the result of millions of years of trial and error, where our most useful characteristics were passed on through survival of the fittest. But this doesn't explain why we have eyebrows. As far as we can tell, they serve no real evolutionary purpose, but they are very useful for self-expression. Also, we are the only species who experiences emotional crying. No one has a really good evolutionary explanation for why we do this. Bryson repeated over and over, "the purpose of X is unknown", or "nobody knows why X happens". Several times he described an attribute of the human body and then said that it was "one of life's many imponderables". There is no denying that we know far more than we did 100 years ago, but I'm sure the same will be said of us 100 years from now. Of course, any book exploring the science of the human body is going to end by talking about death. I learned that heart disease is the number one cause of death in America and kills more people than cancer, influenza, pneumonia, and accidents combined. We hear so much about cancer and are often worried about getting it (rightly so), but in reality we should be worried about taking better care of our hearts. One in three Americans dies of heart disease. Bryson also shared this little nugget: the average body in a sealed coffin takes between 5 and 40 years to decompose. Lovely thought. Bryson ended the book with a great line. After talking about burial and cremation, he abruptly says "And that's you gone. But was fun while it lasted." It was just a funny way to end, and it fit perfectly with his quippy sense of humor. Excellent book, and highly recommended.

Bill Bryson is one of the most widely read and beloved writers on so many subjects, be it travelogues to obscure locations, the history of the universe, and now the most ridiculous subject of them all, your body. Just kidding, not YOUR body, but the human body, and at all times Bryson is an erudite and irreverent guide through this endlessly fascinating subject, right up to the various ways the body expires.For me, the most interesting area discussed was the evolution of our knowledge of nutrition since those of us even just over the age of 30 can remember when nutritional and dietary suggestions were quite different than they are now. Bryson is an effective guide through a lot of the unscientific BS that pervades these discussions and offers an up to date account of proper amounts of exercise and nutritive consumption. He also details where some of these misconceptions may have come from, usually a misreading of a single study that was leaded to the popular media. Bryson is also quite clear where we still have no idea as to why certain things happen, or exist, or how to combat them and this forms at times the most distressing aspect of the work, though obviously necessary. The quick little asides and meanderings on how incredible some aspects of our regular functioning are, make for great reading especially in the chapter on all of the various chemicals your body uses and produces on a regular basis. As I mentioned, Bryson can be irreverent and waggish when discussing certain things and this pervades the chapter on sex. One clean but perfectly expressed point on why we may have evolved to engage in this practice instead of mere cloning by single-sex organisms occurs later in the work:"Sex may dilute our personal contribution to posterity, but it is great for the species. By mixing and matching genes, we get variety and that gives us safety and resilience. It makes it harder for diseases to sweep through whole populations. It also means that we can evolve. We can hold on to beneficial genes and discard ones that impede our collective happiness. Cloning gives you the same thing over and over. Sex gives you Einstein and Rembrandt - and a lot of dorks, too, of course."Those wanting a more academic appraisal of these areas along with an examination of our evolutionary history should definitely check out Harvard Professor Daniel Lieberman's, "The Story of the Human Body." Lieberman is someone, also, that Bryson references heavily throughout the work. However those looking for an up to date appraisal of the human body from a masterful storyteller should also consider this fantastic volume.

Still trying to get some walking in (early in the morning before many people are out) so I was able to chomp through the last chapters of this in a couple of days. Recommend if you like a good non-fiction deep dive, bonus if you're looking for a long audiobook.

Does what it says on the tin. And reads exactly as you would expect from Bryson: well written, well researched, informative, revealing and entertaining. One factor that stood out for me was the sheer number of times that a scientific or medical theory took flight, was seized upon by the media, and stuck as a firmly believed fact despite subsequent research that proves the theory to have no scientific basis or 100% proven to be wrong. It's quite scary how much this happens. But because whole industries emerge to capitalise on what are ultimately urban legends, they are incredibly hard to quash. This book might as easily been titled Health, and there is unavoidable overlap in the subject matter, but it seemed the second half of the book was primarily focused on health and disease. And this is where a small but disappointing element here poked its head out. Although still a bit niche/controversial there's a steadily growing acceptance by medical professionals, that psychogenic disease is a grossly underestimated factor in our health, particularly in the area of chronic pain. The chapter on chronic pain was either disappointingly researched or deliberately ignored, despite evidence that would be hard to miss if investigating this area, so I suspect the latter. There were many points in the book, where the evidence was right there in his own words, yet he chose not to acknowledge it. There was even a chapter about Akureyri disease, which broke out in Iceland in the 1940s where no physical factors could be found and scientists concluded its genesis as psychogenic "which means" Bryson says "they had no idea whatsoever what caused it". It absolutely doesn't mean that Bill! It means it was psychogenic! I love Bryson but that is one of the most ignorant or deliberately obtuse lines I've ever read. A small factor overall. But it left a bad taste.To end on a better note, I actually wailed "Oh no" when I realised Bryson was narrating his own book. He does not have a good track record, whereas his regular narrator William Roberts does an amazing job of capturing the personality in his writing, an endeavour the author has failed to do in previous recordings. However, I think he's had some coaching, as he was a lot more engaging than past narrations.

I like Bill Bryson. I read and enjoyed:" A short walk" & "A sunburned country", but I lost my patience with "A short history of nearly everything". I blame myself for that. What was I expecting? With this latest book, I have to say, it is not a book to read all the way through. It's probably the only book I'll ever recommend for those of you who like to have reading material accessible in the bathroom. You could read it in limited amounts of time and never run out of reading material or patience. It's really fascinating when taken in little bits at a time. For example did you know that if your lungs were stretched out and flattened they would cover a tennis court? And so on. But you can see why you wouldn't want to sit down and read it from start to finish or worse, listen to your partner reading it aloud to you in bed before you fall asleep which I guarantee you will not be long. For example, did you know that in 2018, a professor at Oxford found that low-dose aspirin is not effective at all in reducing cardiac or cancer risk in anyone weighing 154 pounds or more--but it does still post a serious risk of internal bleeding.etc.,etc.,etc. All good information in low doses. No pun intended.

I have really enjoyed most of Bill Bryson's books but really struggled to find anything likeable about this one. I normally finish a book in 2 days and this took me 25 days to finish because I kept putting it down. He lists some facts about each area of the body and the scientists that studied it, whether those facts are interesting or not. Sometimes he gets into the subject matter and briefly writes in an engaging way, but most of the time it reads like a list of bullet points he jotted down while reading something else. He cribs very heavily from Mary Roach's works and always gives her credit but trust me, it's more fun and engaging to read her amazing books directly instead of this summary of Bill's. It's tedious, I felt like most of the facts were obvious things I learned in primary school or summaries from better books I had already read, and found his super repetitive negative comments about fat people a bit hypocritical and mean. I've already had 2 of my home library clients return it and say they didn't like it and couldn't finish it, so I am not going to recommend it to anyone.

How can you not like this? It's another of Bryson's fact and trivia books, this time covering the body from top to toe - in a sense - and uncovering all manner of interesting information about how the body ticks, and about the people who made the discoveries. And how there's still a great deal we just don't know about the body, even though you'd think we were up with the play completely by now. As always the anecdotal material is fascinating: the scientists who literally killed themselves in various ways to make discoveries - or unwittingly killed themselves while making discoveries. The scientists who didn't discover something new but claimed they did, and caused the real discoverer to be cast in the background. The scientists who did all manner of appalling things to themselves and others in order to learn about how our bodies work, and the men and women who healed others by trying something different instead of something that killed as many as it cured. It can be almost overwhelming, but you read on, because after all, who isn't interested in their own body and what's going on inside it?

Bryson is always intelligent, quirky, and entertaining and The Body is all of that. He takes often dry factual material and enlivens it. The organization of the book, by body sections and systems, is clear. His interjection of strange stories about the personalities and lives of some significant medical researchers adds to the fun.The very last chapters are somewhat different. Instead of describing physiological facts, he begins talking about the health care systems in different countries. He compares death rates, death causes, number of tests run, and of course, cost. Some might find this off-putting but it seemed to me to be germane when talking about the body. He ends naturally enough by talking about dying and again discusses different death experiences according to various factors. All in all, a book that informs but holds your attention and encourages pondering. Thanks to the publisher and to Net Galley for providing me with an ARC in exchange for my honest review.

This is one of the most interesting and fascinating books I have ever read. It is also at times horrifying, especially when the chapters talk about research, pharmaceuticals and medical tests. I wasn't going to read it when I first heard of it because I thought it would be too "scientific" and hard to read. Having read most all of Bill Bryson's books, I should have known better. It is easy to understand and sprinkled with his own brand of laugh out loud funny asides. The amount of research that goes into any excellent non-fiction book is always amazing to me. Besides Bryson, I enjoy any non-fiction by Erik Larson, Simon Winchester and David McCullough. If you like to learn while reading an enjoyable "story", I high recommend all these authors. That said, Bill Bryon's "The Body" is one of the very best!

Well, Bill Bryson has done it again! This book moves into my top-ten list and I'd easily give it a higher than 5-star rating. Highly recommended!So why the superb rating? First, I enjoyed it to the point where I'd reread it sometime soon. Bryson's writing style is relaxed, humorous, and extremely easy to follow. Second, I learned a LOT, and his tendency to explore immensely interesting bunny trails contributes mightily to the enjoyment. He never takes himself too seriously. I feel like he is a "reader's author". In other words, he makes great effort to make his books page-turners for the average reader like me.I won't summarize the book, you can get that from the jacket. Just be prepared to laugh while you learn an amazing amount - read "The Body" by Bill Bryson.

"The day when people once again die from the scratch of a rose thorn may not be far away."I loved this book. Full of easily digestible scientific facts, historic stories, and unexpected connections that all relate to our bodies. It is entertaining to read while being quite educational and even mesmerizing at times. I would even recommend this read to a doctor, not just a lay person, particularly specialists that don't always look at the whole body in the diagnosis and treatment of disease... a lot of good reminders what and where to look. Fascinating for any age or profession/educational background.

A well compiled and written book of facts about the human body, accesible and entertaining (as well as horrifying in some instances) A book that I appropriatly read near halloween due to some of it's morbidity, but there is also a great deal of light heartedness and Bill is a good guide with his dryness.The parts of it are well put togethor in well thought out way, displaying the most interesting and important facts without going on too long.I learnt a lot of interesting facts as well as some grisly tales to spook some of my friends if such an appropriate time comes along, along with humorous tales of discovery and facinating things, of course.

Very interesting read but the stories are too Americentric. Makes me wonder how many interesting scientists, doctors etc. from different countries were also omitted (purposefully or not, it's hard to tell).

The Body: A Guide for Occupants (2019) by Bill Bryson is an entertaining, informative book that takes the reader on a tour of our bodies.The Body is really a lot of fun and the descriptions of skin, hair, stomachs, food, brains, bones, cancer, DNA and everything else and the people who discovered how they work and what makes them go wrong is really well done. There are just so many interesting anecdotes and facts and they really are delivered well.The Body is a highly enjoyable and is very much worth a read.

There will be many more years until we finally discover the true potential and solve the human body puzzle or we may never be able to. Regardless, Bill Bryson tried to explain this wonder in a simple and interesting way. Great book.

Much like his previous book, "A Short History of Nearly Everything", "The Body" offers a brief and entertaining tour to the human body. Another entertaining and informative masterpiece from Bill Bryson. It's always fun listening to the author read his works. I learned so much new information about "the body" and even the stuff I had heard before was presented with a fresh outlook. Bryson is a true wordsmith and his delivery is always interesting and witty. But the author tackles difficult topics such as medical 'advances,' historical and modern medicine and he has an amazing command of his subject.

I am so grateful to Doubleday books for the eARC of Bill Bryson’s The Body. This book embodies all of my favorite kinds of science writing - it takes a topic we are all familiar with, our bodies, and then lets the reader see their own body in a new way. I am constantly on the lookout for books to share with my anatomy students, and this has catapulted to the top of my stack! It is wonderfully thorough, but Bryson’s wit & writing style make it easy to digest.

Not as many caveats re: research methodologies and current scientific blindspots, but still a lovely book. Lovingly presented with humour and kindness and great attention to detail. Bryson does another remarkable job of packaging information and making it both informative and entertaining. As always, Bryson’s writing is easily read as he hops from one anecdote to another, reintroducing us to the sense of awe for inhabiting our incredible bodies. (audio version) Bryson at his very best. A measured, well paced journey through what we know (and just as interestingly what we don't know) about the human body. Educational, entertaining, sometimes frightening, funny - doffing his cap to a number of unsung heroes of the medical world.I would recommend this book (certainly the audio version) to anyone.

UGH. If I wanted someone to just read an anatomy encyclopedia to me then this book would nail it. Not sure how this topic could possibly be made SO DRY but this book was a slog. I got through 6 hours of the audiobook before giving up. No sign of typical Bill Bryson wit and humor anywhere to be found. I’ve always loved his user friendly and personable take on science but this is none of that.

I always enjoy a good Bill Bryson book. This novel is a brief overview of just about everything having to do with your body and how it functions. Review title: Be glad you're aliveBruce Springsteen is indeed right: it ain't no sin to be glad you're alive, an emotion you'll feel after reading about the body through Bill Bryson's pen. It's a marvelous machine--no, far better actually, Bryson realizes and writes: no machine made by man has yet had (and likely never will) the complexity, strength, flexibility, endurance, and intelligence of the human body. It's a good place to live. Bryson has written about pretty much everything from hiking the Appalachian Trail to living in England to--well, everything (A Short History of Everything was the first of his books I read), always with a sense of humor and curiosity about the world around him. He is an American transplant to the UK where he met his wife and they have spent most of their married years, but he retains an American view of the world (yes there is one, identifiable by passers-by on the street even without hearing the accent, a British coworker and friend assures me) and the body even as he interviews experts and includes examples from both countries. As Bryson tours around and through the body chapter by chapter it is astonishing how much is unique about humans from other members of the animal kingdom, how intricately things fit together and work in the only way they possibly could, and how little we know about how and why the body and its parts work. Bryson describes these intricate mechanics, chemistry, and physics as the end result of genetic mutation or environmental adaptation and often gently deflects away theories of intelligent design, even when the statistical probability of evolution approaches impossibly small numbers. This isn't a medical textbook or how-to guide to personal health and body maintenance. It is just a fun exercise in curiosity about the shell our minds, souls, and lives occupy, and the scientists and medical doctors and experimenters who have poked and prodded it through the centuries. The usual suspects are in play (da Vinci, Harvey, Salk) but leave it to Bryson to highlight the often oddball men and women who haven't been given the credit they deserve. It is astonishing how little was known two centuries ago, last century, even last decade and how wrong prevailing theories and treatments were then; it raises the question of how astonishing current medical practices will appear to our grandchildren just a few decades hence. It was also written and published before the corona virus pandemic exploded, so it does not specifically address the virus, although he does write about why pharmaceutical companies are investing less and less time and money in research and development of drugs to treat these new environmental risks; as a consequence, Bryson concludes prophetically, "In the event of a really catastrophic epidemic--one that killed children or young adults in large numbers, say--Kinch believes we wouldn't be able to produce vaccine fast enough to treat everyone, even if the vaccine was effective." (p. 334) Of course, any medical cure is far from a sure thing. Bryson notes how while we are by far healthier globally on average due to the defeat of major infectious diseases--tuberculosis, pneumonia, and most influenzas--by a small set of treatments, more people now face health risks from lifestyle choices. Indeed, the average American life span suffers in comparison to the citizens of most modern advanced economies, despite spending far more per capita on health care than other nations. We're overstuffed (eating 20% more calories per day on average than citizens of healthier European countries, Bryson says), oversedentary due to desk jobs and television obsessions, and oversedated on medications that have marginal benefits or lead to prescription drug dependency. This is still the best time to be alive for every human in every country, and America is still a great country with great doctors and nurses, but pushing away from the pizza, putting down the remote, and considering improvements to the economic and political climate of health care could benefit every body.It's no sin to be glad you're alive in the body you've been given. Enjoy it with the curiosity and the attention it deserves courtesy of Bryson.

“Guide” is an appropriate word as Bryson leads the reader into the many and mysterious complexities of the human body . He begins with the chemical components that make up the body, the major components being oxygen and carbon, the rest being smaller, mostly trace elments, fifty-seven or so of them. From here, he works his way down the body from the head to the extremities, inside and out, and relates all of this information in clear and occasional wryly humorous language  The human body is made up of configurations, some of which we share with other mammals, and some which are uniquely human. Some of these differences can be explained by evolutionary processes, some remain a puzzle as how they developed or why they’re there, the appendix or tonsils being good examples. One thing that Bryson is very good at is giving the history of discoveries about the body. A few explorers’ names are familiar but for the most part these individuals have long since been forgotten, even though the discoveries of these unsung heroes, particularly in the area of diseases, have been important. Research on the body is ongoing, and it’s doubtful it will ever cease, as the body is always changing in subtle and complex ways that we don’t fully understand and will always need further study.  Perhaps the best way to get a sense of this book is to look at the table of contents. Bryson begins with the body’s covering, the skin, and this leads to a discussion of the trillions of microbes that pass through our coverings and their openings.  That taken care of, Bryson take on the brain, its covering, the head or skull, “down the hatch” of the mouth and throat, an excursion into the “chemistry department” (what goes wrong, for example, in the case of diabetes), then back to the skeleton, the immune system, lungs and breathing, and finally into the intestines or gurts. What makes the book particularly interesting are related topics that these body parts give rise to. The skeleton, for instance, leads into chapters on equilibrium, movement, and exercise. The immune system is connected to diseases (when things go wrong). Related topics are nerves and pain, medicine, food (“food, glorious food”) and diet.  It’s not just the parts of the body that are being discussed, but how the body functions, and dysfunctions, how it works, or doesn’t work, in all kinds of ways. A healthy body is always of interest, and even though our end, death and the disintegration of the body, is inevitable, human beings have always wanted to get to the end in reasonably good shape. The book, then, in addition to being a guide to the exploration and explanation of body parts, , is also a guide as to how we best occupy and use that body. The answers are not always evident, but Bryson seems to have done thorough and credible research into these murky areas.
